lines.text: Mmh, mmh
lines.translation: Mmh, mmh
lines.grammar: This interjection "Mmh" is an informal expression of agreement or confirmation in French, often used to show understanding or empathy.

lines.text: Viens dans mes bras, viens
lines.translation: Come into my arms, come
lines.grammar: The imperative verb "viens" is in the second person singular, addressing a single person to come into your arms. The repeated phrase creates an intimate and inviting atmosphere, emphasizing the urgency of the request.

lines.text: Viens dans mes bras, parle-moi tout doucement
lines.translation: Come into my arms, speak to me very softly
lines.grammar: The verb "parle-moi" is in the imperative mood, used to give a command or make a request. The pronoun "moi" is an object pronoun and agrees with the subject "vous" (you) in the implied sentence.

lines.text: Viens dans mes bras, viens dans mes bras
lines.translation: Come into my arms, come into my arms
lines.grammar: The imperative mood is used to express a direct command or request, as in "viens" and "viens", which are repeated for emphasis. The use of the same verb form with different pronouns ("mes bras") emphasizes possession and intimacy.

lines.text: Et parle-moi tout doucement
lines.translation: And speak to me very softly
lines.grammar: The phrase "parle-moi" is an idiomatic expression that uses the informal "tu" form of the verb "parler" and the pronoun "moi" to convey a sense of intimacy, emphasizing the speaker's desire for gentle communication.

lines.text: J'osais pas te le dire, tu me rends bête
lines.translation: I didn't dare tell you, you make me feel stupid
lines.grammar: The phrase "j'osais pas" is an idiomatic expression in the present perfect tense, indicating the speaker's reluctance to do something. The verb "osai" is in the conditional imperfect tense, implying a hypothetical situation.

lines.text: J'veux revoir ton sourire donc, je m'endette
lines.translation: I want to see your smile again, so I'm going into debt.
lines.grammar: The phrase "je m'endette" is an idiomatic expression meaning "to go into debt", using the reflexive pronoun "me" to emphasize the speaker's willingness to take on financial risk.

lines.text: Pense à moi (quand ça va), n'oublie pas (n'oublie pas)
lines.translation: Think of me (when things are going well), don't forget (don't forget)
lines.grammar: The use of "quand ça va" is an idiomatic expression indicating a condition for thinking about someone, whereas "n'oublie pas" is an imperative sentence with a repetitive particle emphasizing the importance of not forgetting.

lines.text: Que j'étais là (j'étais là) quand ça n'allait pas (ah, ah)
lines.translation: That I was there (I was there) when things weren't going well (ah, ah)
lines.grammar: The use of the past imperfect tense "j'étais" emphasizes the ongoing nature of the situation, implying that the speaker's presence was a constant factor throughout. The repeated phrase "j'étais là" also serves as an idiomatic expression to stress the importance of being present at a particular moment.

lines.text: Ah, ah, ah, ah, ah, ah, ah, ah

lines.grammar: This line is an example of a repeated interjection, used to express strong emotions or emphasis. The use of the same phrase multiple times creates a sense of rhythm and emphasizes the speaker's feelings.

lines.grammar: The use of "ah" and the repetition of "tu me rends" creates an idiomatic expression conveying strong emotions, emphasizing the speaker's frustration. The imperative mood and informal tone convey a sense of exasperation.

lines.text: J'vais quitter l'Europe, j'monte dans l'avion
lines.translation: I'm leaving Europe, I'm getting on the plane
lines.grammar: This line uses the informal "je vais" construction to express future intention, equivalent to "I'm going to" in English. The use of "j'" instead of "je" is a common spoken French idiom, similar to dropping the "g" from "going to".

lines.text: Je chеcke le pilote, j'bloque
lines.translation: I'm checking the driver, I'm stuck
lines.grammar: The phrase "j'bloque" is an idiomatic expression meaning "to be stuck" or "to be in a difficult situation", using the verb bloquer in the present tense to convey a sense of being trapped.

lines.text: J't'ai vue à l'avant dans la rame
lines.translation: I saw you at the front of the train.
lines.grammar: The informal pronoun "j'" is used to indicate a familiar relationship with the listener, and the verb "vue" is in the passé composé tense, indicating that the action happened before the moment of speaking.

lines.text: J'me canalise pas, faut qu'je te parle (han, han, han)
lines.translation: I can't control myself, I need to talk to you (han, han, han)
lines.grammar: The phrase "j'me" is a casual, informal way of saying "je me" in French, used to emphasize the speaker's emotional state. The verb "canalise" is in the present tense and has an idiomatic meaning of losing control or being overwhelmed.

lines.text: Porsche Carrera, j'frappe fort comme Pereira
lines.translation: Porsche Carrera, I hit hard like Pereira
lines.grammar: The phrase "j'frappe fort" is an idiomatic expression meaning "I'm doing something well" or "I excel at something", using the informal "je" and the verb "frapper" in its figurative sense.

lines.text: Grosse caille-ra, toi et moi devant les caméras
lines.translation: You and me, you big thug, in front of the cameras
lines.grammar: The phrase "caille-ra" is an idiomatic expression used to address someone informally, with a tone of familiarity and even mockery. The use of "toi" instead of "vous" emphasizes the informal nature of the interaction.

lines.text: Viens dans mes bras, dans mes draps, sur Telegram
lines.translation: Come into my arms, into my sheets, on Telegram
lines.grammar: The phrase "Viens dans mes bras" is an idiomatic expression that uses the imperative mood to convey a sense of intimacy and invitation. The verb "viens" is in the second person singular form, indicating direct address to someone.

lines.text: Tu s'ras à moi quand l'avion atterrira
lines.translation: You'll be mine when the plane lands
lines.grammar: The phrase "Tu s'ras" is a future tense construction, using the verb "être" in the subjunctive mood to express a hypothetical or uncertain situation. The pronoun "tu" agrees with the subject of the sentence, indicating a direct address.

lines.text: Donc, on s'évade, on s'efface, j'fais pas de vagues
lines.translation: So, we escape, we disappear, I don't make waves
lines.grammar: The use of "on" instead of "je" or "nous" to refer to the speaker's actions is an idiomatic expression in French, indicating a casual and informal tone.

lines.text: J'fais pas de blagues, j'vais bientôt t'passer la bague

lines.text: Ça faisait longtemps qu'toi et moi, on n's'était pas brouillé comme ça
lines.translation: It's been a long time since you and I had such a falling out.
lines.grammar: The use of "faisait" instead of "fait" indicates the past perfect tense, emphasizing that the period without conflict was longer than just the duration of the conflict itself. The phrase "Ça faisait longtemps" is an idiomatic expression equivalent to "It's been a long time".

lines.text: C'est pour ça qu'on se débat
